image.altText: Philip Lowe sitting at a desk behind a microphone mid-sentence, gesturing with his right hand and looking at the camera

items.synopsis: The ABC can confirm Philip Lowe will not be re-appointed as Reserve Bank of Australia governor.

title.children: Philip Lowe will not be re-appointed as RBA governor

image.altText: Reserve Bank of Australia

items.synopsis: The next RBA governor will be announced after a cabinet meeting this morning, following the confirmation that the current governor, Philip Lowe, will not have his term renewed. Follow live.

title.children: Next RBA governor to be announced after cabinet meeting

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Apart from being the ninth RBA governor in the bank's history (since its split from the government in 1959), Philip Lowe's successor could make history for another reason. The RBA has never had a female governor in its history — and there are two women who are on the shortlist to lead the bank from September. The first is Michele Bullock, who is the current deputy RBA governor. She's been in the job since April 2022 The second is Jenny Wilkinson, who is currently the head of the Finance department. She's no stranger to making history either — she was the first woman appointed to lead the Finance department.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: History could be made with the next RBA governor

children.content: Apart from being the ninth RBA governor in the bank's history (since its split from the government in 1959), Philip Lowe's successor could make history for another reason.
The
RBA has never had a female governor in its history
— and there are two women who are on the shortlist to lead the bank from September.
The first is
Michele Bullock
, who is the current deputy RBA governor. She's been in the job since April 2022
The second is
Jenny Wilkinson
, who is currently the head of the Finance department. She's no stranger to making history either — she was the first woman appointed to lead the Finance department.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: He may be unpopular among many Australian households, but Philip Lowe's exit from being the RBA governor isn't because he's been shown the door. Instead, it's because his term as RBA governor is expiring in September. RBA governors are appointed once every seven years, and there have only been eight governors since the RBA split from the federal government in 1959.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Why is Philip Lowe being replaced?

children.content: He may be unpopular among many Australian households, but Philip Lowe's exit from being the RBA governor isn't because he's been shown the door.
Instead, it's because
his term as RBA governor is expiring
in September.
RBA governors are appointed once every seven years
, and there have only been eight governors since the RBA split from the federal government in 1959.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: There are a few names that have been circulating as possibilities that could take over from current RBA governor Philip Lowe. He will remain governor until September, but here's a quick look at who we could see announced as his successor later today.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Who is in the running to replace Philip Lowe?

children.content: There are a few names that have been circulating as possibilities that could take over from current RBA governor Philip Lowe.
He will
remain governor until September
, but here's a quick look at who we could see announced as his successor later today.

image.altText: Side photo of Queensland police car.

items.synopsis: It took eight fire crews almost four hours to extinguish the blaze, which destroyed a house in the rural town of Woolooga. The body of a woman was found inside the gutted property.

title.children: Woman's body discovered after fire destroys house in Gympie region

image.altText: Peter Dutton rubs his eye.

items.synopsis: The Federal by-election for the seat of Fadden could deliver a blow or a boost for Peter Dutton next week, writes Michelle Grattan.

title.children: A huge hurdle is coming for Dutton — but a bigger challenge is right behind

image.altText: A small, three-storey unit complex built in red brick is surrounded by large white high-rise apartment towers.

items.synopsis: Unit owners living in some of Queensland's most in-demand real estate hotspots fear proposed changes to the state's body corporate laws could allow developers to squeeze them out of their homes.

title.children: Penned in by high-rises, these unit owners fear body corporate law reform could see them forced out

image.altText: Australian Foreign Minister Penny Wong speaks during meeting.

items.synopsis: The Australian foreign minister says China needs to continue to free up trade for Australian products if Anthony Albanese is to visit there later this year.

title.children: Penny Wong in frank talks with China over trade and human rights at ASEAN summit

image.altText: John Kerry with grey hair wearing a royal blue jacket with a purple tie, looking up wiht his hand raised

items.synopsis: John Kerry, the US special envoy on climate change, told a congressional hearing the government would not contribute to a fund to pay countries that have been damaged by climate-driven disasters.

title.children: US will 'under no circumstances' pay climate reparations to developing countries

image.altText: a woman with a shaved head looking into the camera

items.synopsis: Queensland has 15 Murri Courts, made specifically for First Nations defendants — but not a single one in Logan, which has one of the highest Indigenous populations in the state.

title.children: Rising number of Indigenous defendants prompts call for Murri court in Logan

image.altText: two women with light-coloured short curly hair sitting next to each other smiling

items.synopsis: When was the last time you sought out your local COVID statistics? Many Queenslanders have gone from checking them daily to barely looking at all — but some are still desperate to stay up-to-date.

title.children: Queenslanders aren't checking COVID stats like they used to, but Lorraine says the numbers are still important

image.altText: Fran Drescher outrage and pointing a figure in front of SAG AFTRA signage.

items.synopsis: Screen Actors Guild president Fran Drescher says "we are the victims here", as Hollywood actors join writers on strike.

title.children: Hollywood actors join writers in strike for first time in more than six decades

image.altText: Southern Queensland vegetable grower Tony Gibb squats in a field of cauliflower in a paddock near Toowoomba, July 2023.

items.synopsis: Tony Gibb employs hundreds of people to help run his farm – but with the climate one of his key challenges, he's also now got a world-leading climate scientist on the books.

title.children: As a possible El Niño looms, what will this mean for the people growing your food?

image.altText: Marketa Vondrousova sinks to her knees on Wimbledon's Centre Court.

items.synopsis: Elina Svitolina's comeback dream is shattered by another on a similar path as Ons Jabeur once again looks for history and Wimbledon final redemption.

title.children: Tennis history guaranteed to be made in Wimbledon ladies' singles final

image.altText: A young Thai man holds up one finger while surrounded by photographers

items.synopsis: The leader of Thailand's pro-reform party has been blocked from taking power. Here's what could happen next.

title.children: Thailand's only candidate for PM was blocked from power. Here's why that could trigger 'an uprising'

image.altText: Smiling person, short brown hair, hands on hip, wears Australian Army uniform dress. Sunshine, blurred house, greenery behind.

items.synopsis: When Captain Jesse Noble realised they were gender diverse, it felt like being " hit in the face with a truck". A Christian marriage, their faith, and their career in the army were all at stake.

title.children: How Jesse's dress is overturning the army's gender diversity policy

image.altText: A composite image of a woman wearing a blue saree next to a Barbie doll wearing a saree

items.synopsis: Sixty-four years ago, women all around the world couldn't see themselves as Barbie: a stick-thin doll with big-boobs, blonde hair and blue eyes. Three women share whether that's changed for them.

title.children: Barbie went from a stick-thin blonde to saris and nose rings. But has she changed enough?

image.altText: A hand caresses a platypus resting on a blanket.

items.synopsis: The death of a platypus found in a city suburb may reflect the fate of the entire species if we don't pay closer attention to how this Australian animal is faring.

title.children: The platypus survived megafauna and continental drift, but can it survive us?

image.altText: Commonwealth Bank chief executive Matt Comyn looks at the camera in an office setting.

items.synopsis: Only 60 per cent of the Reserve Bank's increases in the cash rate have been felt by households so far, says CBA boss.

title.children: Young renters under most strain, but full mortgage pain yet to be felt, warns CBA boss

image.altText: A father holds a baby, as he stands at a window.

items.synopsis: Australian men are reporting high-level loneliness. These experts are trying to understand why, and what can be done to fix the problem.

title.children: Which age group of men are the loneliest? This survey had surprising results

image.altText: a group of politicians pile on and shove eachother in parliament.

items.synopsis: Water is thrown before a brawl erupts between politicians and Kosovo's parliament descends into chaos.

title.children: Brawl breaks out in Kosovo parliament after prime minister is showered with water

image.altText: A large white space rocket sits on a railway platform, surrounded by forest with some people seen nearby.

items.synopsis: India aims to become just the fourth nation, along with the United States, the former Soviet Union and China, to land spacecraft on the Moon as it tests technology it hopes to use in future interplanetary missions.

title.children: India to launch its latest lunar rocket as it moves towards a manned mission to the Moon

image.altText: Vince Colosimo walks out of court with his lawyer.

items.synopsis: Lawyers for the 56-year-old said the film and TV star had struggled with mental health and substance abuse issues while racking up more than $60,000 in fines.

title.children: Actor Vince Colosimo has tens of thousands in traffic fines wiped by court

image.altText: Russian Major General Ivan Popov in a military uniform.

items.synopsis: Claims a Russian general says he has been dismissed as a commander after telling the military leadership about the dire situation on the frontline in Ukraine.

title.children: Russian general dismissed after accusing top officers of betraying soldiers

image.altText: A man in his sixties with black glasses, blue shirt, black jacket and red tie.

items.synopsis: The actor told the court he could not believe one of the complainants would "stab me in the back".

title.children: Actor Kevin Spacey tells London court he was 'crushed' by sexual assault allegations

image.altText: A woman in a hard hat has her back to the camera and stands on Whakaari.

items.synopsis: The criminal trial into the Whakaari White Island disaster in New Zealand hears evidence from its first Australian witness, including details of their harrowing journey back to the mainland.

title.children: After she was covered in hot volcanic ash, travel blogger Annie endured a horrifying journey to get help

image.altText: A woman sits at a table typing on a laptop in front of a white wall. An artwork next to her of an eyeball appears to look at her

items.synopsis: Thousands of Australian public sector staff will be allowed to permanently work from home following a "groundbreaking" union deal — but business lobby groups in one capital city say any move to follow suit at local level would be a "death knell" for CBD retail.

title.children: Work-from-home deal 'groundbreaking', but business groups warn of CBD 'death knell'

image.altText: A young Thai man in a suit with his hands clasped before him

items.synopsis: The leader of election winning party Move Forward ran unopposed but couldn't gather the required support of more than half of the 749-member parliament, despite the backing of an eight-party alliance.

title.children: Thailand's Pita Limjaroenrat defeated in parliament bid for prime minister

image.altText: Ben Roberts-Smith arrives at court

items.synopsis: A judge who dismissed Ben Roberts-Smith’s defamation case placed weight on unreliable or improbable accounts from witnesses and "cherry-picked" from the testimony of others, the war veteran will argue during an appeal.

title.children: Ben Roberts-Smith judge accused of 'cherry-picking' evidence as war veteran's lawyers launch appeal

image.altText: A large crowd of African women and children in colourful clothing wait in queues in a sandy desert environment.

items.synopsis: At least 87 people — some of them from the ethnic African Masalit tribe — were killed by the paramilitary Rapid Support Forces (RSF) and an affiliated Arab militia, the UN Human Rights Office said.

title.children: Mass grave with at least 87 bodies found in Sudan's volatile Darfur region

image.altText: An indigenous man and woman wearing a red and white football jersey with their hands on their hips.

items.synopsis: From the west coast of the United States, rapper The Kid LAROI is making his mark on his former hometown in outback New South Wales.

title.children: Rapper The Kid LAROI sponsors outback footy club's Indigenous guernsey

image.altText: five young girl soccer players in uniform on a soccer field

items.synopsis: In south-western Sydney, the Gregory Hills Football Club's under nine girls team have been training hard to follow in the footsteps of the Matildas.

title.children: Future Matildas to take football to 'next level' ahead of Women's World Cup

image.altText: a man in a kandura stands inside a car dalership surrounded by luxury cars

items.synopsis: The self described 'Car Expert' is accused of promoting wrong and offensive mental images of Emirati citizens.

title.children: TikTok star arrested in Dubai over video poking fun at Emiratis

image.altText: a handful of free-range eggs

items.synopsis: An egg industry advocate says farmers will need to be compensated if a suggested end date for battery hens in Australia becomes a reality.

title.children: Battery eggs on the way out — eventually — as ministers agree they have to go

image.altText: Manasseh Sogavare and Li Qiang review an honor guard during a welcome ceremony as they walk a red carpet.

items.synopsis: Solomon Islands prime minister wraps up a week-long visit to Beijing by lavishing praise on China, suggesting the country has been unfairly tarred by the West and has no "strategic interests" in the Pacific.

image.altText: Rho Ophiuchi cloud complex, with brightly-coloured space plumes of space dust and stars

items.synopsis: The James Webb Space Telescope has given us another stunning image, this time revealing a close up a stellar nursery.

title.children: NASA's 'chaotic' new image reveals detail undetectable to the human eye

image.altText: Hayley Atwell, a white brunette woman, and Tom Cruise, a white brunette middle-aged man, are in a car looking at the rear window

items.synopsis: The now late-middle-aged Ethan Hunt returns with his posse of sidekick operatives to take down a menacing sentient AI — and a few past foes — one analog stunt at a time.

title.children: Mission Impossible 7 promised Tom Cruise’s irresistibly deranged Hollywood charm — did it deliver?
